awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Quantum Dynamics of Photochemical Reactions in Solar Energy Conversions
awd_abstract_narration:
Pengfei Huo of the University of Rochester is supported by a CAREER award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry for theoretical research relevant to solar energy conversion. Huo and coworkers develop new quantum dynamics approaches for investigating photochemical reaction.  These reactions are crucial for solar fuel production.  In solar-to-fuel reactions, a molecule is excited by absorption of light, and this process allows the molecule to transfer of both electrons and protons to another molecule.  A quantitative and predictive understanding of these reactions is hampered by the lack of efficient and accurate theoretical approaches.  The Huo group develops new quantum dynamics methods that aim to address these theoretical challenges. They use  computational tools to simulate coupled electron and proton transfer reactions in photocatalytic conversions. Such insights inspire new design principles and paradigms for next-generation photocatalytic energy production.  Dr. Huo's research program is integrated with an educational component centered on theoretical chemistry, including the 'Journey to the Molecular World' summer school for high school students in the Rochester City School District.  This project aims to inspires student curiosity and enthusiasm about molecular science and encourage high school students to pursue higher education in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics.

On-the-fly quantum dynamics simulation is one of the most desirable approaches to investigate non-equilibrium photochemical reactions. Accurately performing such simulations remains a significant challenge in theoretical chemistry, due to a lack of efficient quantum dynamics methods as well as the discrepancy between diabatic dynamics methods and adiabatic electronic structure calculations. To address these long-standing challenges, Dr. Huo and his team are developing new path-integral quantum dynamics approaches that can accurately simulate non-adiabatic electronic transitions and explicitly incorporate nuclear quantum effects through a classical-like description for all degrees of freedom.  They are also developing new propagation schemes that enable a seamless interface between diabatic dynamics methods and adiabatic electronic structure calculations, explicitly avoiding additional efforts to reformulate diabatic dynamics methods to the adiabatic representations. Combining the above two types of techniques, the Huo group is performing on-the-fly simulations to investigate the fundamental mechanisms of photoinduced proton-coupled electron transfer (PI-PCET) reactions which are at the center of many solar energy conversion processes. His team is exploring experimentally-testable mechanistic hypotheses that take advantage of the non-equilibrium and quantum mechanical nature of PI-PCET to achieve new chemical reactivities. These investigations may yield a set of general and widely applicable theoretical tools that can significantly expand the scope of quantum dynamics simulations, as well as provide fundamental knowledge and new design principles to predict and control the reactivities of next-generation photocatalysts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the real-time dynamics of the interactions between molecules and light will significantly advance the design of photocatalytic systems and enable new reactivities.  Accurately and efficiently performing these simulations, however, remains a central challenge in theoretical chemistry. The quantum dynamics aspect of this challenge boils down to two parts: (i) a lack of efficient approaches that can accurately describe electronic non-adiabatic effects and nuclear quantum effects, (ii) the discrepancy between quantum dynamics methods and electronic structure approaches because they are usually developed in two different representations. (iii) the interaction between quantized light field and molecules. In order to address these long-standing fundamental challenges in theoretical chemistry and significantly improve the accuracy and expand the capability of quantum dynamics simulations, we developed several accurate and powerful theoretical approaches. 

(1) We developed a general theoretical framework for computing the time-correlation function (TCF) of electronically non-adiabatic systems, which we referred to as non-adiabatic Matsubara dynamics and non-adiabatic ring polymer molecular dynamics approach. These methods provide a framework with both accurate non-adiabatic effects and nuclear quantum effects.

(2) We developed the quasi-diabatic (QD) propagation scheme that provides a seamless interface between accurate diabatic quantum dynamics approaches and any adiabatic electronic structure calculation. The QD scheme explicitly addresses the discrepancy between these two representations that have hindered such calculations in the past few decades and enables ab initio on-the-fly simulations for diabatic quantum dynamics approaches. It bridges the electronic structure community and quantum dynamics community through a transformative platform and fosters the development of new on-the-fly simulation techniques. 

(3) Using direct quantum dynamics simulations, we have investigated the fundamental mechanism of photo-induced proton-coupled electron transfer reactions without making any a priori mechanistic assumptions, which provides new insights into the coupled transfer of charged particles in solar energy conversion processes. We also presented a new theoretical explanation for the vibrational strong coupling modification of the reaction kinetics when coupling molecules with optical cavities, which could provide the first important step toward unraveling these mystery effects.

We developed a “Journey to the Molecular World” summer program for local high school students from the Rochester City School District (RCSD) who have disadvantaged backgrounds (such as financial hardships and the absence of role models). Since 2017, we have successfully conducted the class twice a year. Each session covers three 1.5-hour-long activities and lectures for 15~20 high school students. Undergraduate students in my group are also actively participating in these activities, serving as the “peer advisors” for the hands-on activities and role models for these high school students. In 2020, we converted the materials to an online Blackboard course. The virtual class successfully attracted over 180 high school students and gained overwhelmingly positive feedback, suggesting these experiences helped students gain direct insight into various chemical phenomena and microscopic understanding of molecular structures.
